title: What happens if you guess? - Leigh Nataro

multiple-choice.question: What is the probability of getting a perfect score by guessing on a 10-question true/false quiz?
What is the fundamental counting principle?

options.label: A
options.text: If there are A possible outcomes for one event, and B possible outcomes for another event, then there are A plus B ways to pair the outcomes.

options.label: B
options.text: If there are A possible outcomes for one event, and B possible outcomes for another event, then there are A minus B ways to pair the outcomes.

options.label: C
options.text: If there are A possible outcomes for one event, and B possible outcomes for another event, then there are A times B ways to pair the outcomes.

options.label: D
options.text: If there are A possible outcomes for one event, and B possible outcomes for another event, then there are A divided by B ways to pair the outcomes.

multiple-choice.question: How many different combinations of answers are possible for a 10-question true/false quiz?
What is the average score that can be expected by randomly guessing on a 10-question true/false quiz?
What is the probability of getting a question right by guessing on a true/false quiz?
If there are 20 questions and five possible answers for each question, what is the probability of getting a question right by guessing?
What is the expected score on a 20-question multiple-choice quiz with five possible answers for each question, if the answers are randomly guessed?
How many different combinations of answers are possible for a 20-question multiple-choice quiz with five possible answers for each question?

options.label: C
options.text: 95 trillion, 365 billion, 431 million, 648 thousand, 625

multiple-choice.question: What is the probability of getting all 20 questions correct by randomly guessing on a 20-question multiple-choice quiz with five possible answers for each question?

options.label: C
options.text: 1/95 trillion

multiple-choice.question: In what situations is probability used?

options.label: A
options.text: Weather forecasts, sports predictions, and setting auto insurance rates

options.label: B
options.text: Medical research, engineering, and finance

options.label: C
options.text: Education, psychology, and sociology

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary role of authentic narrative in connecting people through media?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide a distraction from critical issues

options.label: B
options.text: To make the personal universal and transcend the individual

options.label: C
options.text: To solely focus on data and facts

options.label: D
options.text: To promote trivial stories

multiple-choice.question: What are the three components of sourcing required in every well-reported piece of journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: Official sources, social media, and personal opinions

options.label: B
options.text: Official sources, overview sources, and unofficial sources

options.label: C
options.text: Academics, consultants, and authors

options.label: D
options.text: Stakeholders, experts, and witnesses

multiple-choice.question: Who are considered official sources in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: People directly affected by an event

options.label: B
options.text: Academics and consultants

options.label: C
options.text: People with titles and expertise, such as company owners and spokespeople

options.label: D
options.text: Social media influencers

multiple-choice.question: What type of sources provide the "why" and give consequence to an event or trend?

options.label: A
options.text: Official sources

options.label: B
options.text: Overview sources

options.label: C
options.text: Unofficial sources

options.label: D
options.text: Social media sources

multiple-choice.question: How can journalists mine for compelling stories and anecdotes?

options.label: A
options.text: By asking routine and predictable questions

options.label: B
options.text: By focusing solely on data and facts

options.label: C
options.text: By asking surprising questions

options.label: D
options.text: By ignoring the stories of every subject

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of anecdotes in storytelling?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide unnecessary details

options.label: B
options.text: To breathe life into a grey story of exposition, facts, and data

options.label: C
options.text: To distract from the main issue

options.label: D
options.text: To promote a personal agenda

multiple-choice.question: When is it important to convey information quickly through bulleted facts and updates?

options.label: A
options.text: When telling a personal story

options.label: B
options.text: When providing an overview of a topic

options.label: C
options.text: When a situation is urgent and action is required

options.label: D
options.text: When writing a feature article

multiple-choice.question: What type of stories have the luxury of a slow dance of information?

options.label: A
options.text: Breaking news stories

options.label: B
options.text: Urgent updates

options.label: C
options.text: Narrative personal stories

options.label: D
options.text: Data-driven reports

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of artful solicitation of story in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: A lack of connection with the audience

options.label: B
options.text: A focus on trivial stories

options.label: C
options.text: Memorable journalism that delivers a narrative bond

options.label: D
options.text: A decrease in readership

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of using authentic narrative in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: To win awards and recognition

options.label: B
options.text: To increase readership and revenue

options.label: C
options.text: To connect people and make a story timeless and humanistic

options.label: D
options.text: To promote a personal agenda

title: How fiction can change reality - Jessica Wise

multiple-choice.question: What did Emily Dickinson say was the best way to be transported to new lands?

options.label: A
options.text: Watching a movie

options.label: B
options.text: Reading a book

options.label: C
options.text: Listening to music

options.label: D
options.text: Looking at art

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Change a person's point of view

options.label: C
options.text: Change a person's environment

options.label: D
options.text: Change a person's personality

options.label: A
options.text: Facts and non-fiction

options.label: B
options.text: Fiction and stories

options.label: C
options.text: History and science

options.label: D
options.text: Technology and media

options.label: A
options.text: It was widely ignored

options.label: B
options.text: It caused a lot of debate and discussion

options.label: C
options.text: It was banned due to its content

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: The plots of novels he read

options.label: B
options.text: The scientific discoveries of his time

options.label: C
options.text: The natural world around him

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What do recent studies suggest might be an alternative to the idea of individual heroism?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: A focus on competition and individual achievement

options.label: C
options.text: A focus on technology and innovation

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Because the terrain of the world has changed and we need new perspectives

options.label: C

options.label: C
options.text: "Jane Eyre"

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential impact of stories and literature on our understanding of the world and ourselves?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: They can shape our ideas and influence our perspectives

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: What story will you try on next?

options.label: C
options.text: What author will you study next?

options.label: D
options.text: What genre will you explore next?

options.label: C
options.text: To calculate the area of geometric shapes

options.label: D

options.text: The base number b

options.label: B
options.text: The exponent p

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the difference in water pressure

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the pH of human tears?
What is a common way to remember the formula for logarithms?

options.label: A
options.text: "The base raised to what power equals the number?"

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
